questions.text: A 62-year-old man presents with sudden, severe pain in his right big toe, waking him from sleep. The joint is swollen, red, and extremely tender. He has a history of high uric acid levels and recently consumed protein-rich meals. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 43-year-old man presents with severe pain in his right big toe, redness, and swelling, as shown in the image. He has a history of hypertension and recently increased her consumption of red meat. Which of the following best explains the pathophysiological process leading to her condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased renal tubular secretion of uric acid

options.label: C
options.text: Impaired renal excretion of uric acid

questions.correct_answer: C. Impaired renal excretion of uric acid

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman with a history of elevated uric acid levels reports that she experienced a painful episode in her right big toe two months ago. Since that time, she has had no symptoms and feels completely normal. She is concerned about the possibility of future attacks. What stage of the associated condition is this patient most likely experiencing now?
questions.explanation:
Stage 1: Asymptomatic Hyperuricemia

(Option A ruled out)
  • Elevated serum uric acid levels without any symptoms.
  • It can last for years & individuals may be unaware of their condition.

Stage 2: Acute Gout Attack

(Option B ruled out)
  • A sudden onset of severe pain, redness, and swelling in a joint, most commonly the MTP joint, typically lasts 1–2 weeks.
  • Intense pain, extreme tenderness, and marked swelling with shiny, red skin.
  • Symptoms usually resolve spontaneously.

Stage 3: Intercritical Gout

(Option C)
  • Periods between acute attacks when the patient is symptom-free & intervals vary from weeks to years.
  • No symptoms, but the risk of future attacks remains.

Stage 4: Chronic Gouty Arthritis

(Option D ruled out)
  • Persistent joint inflammation and damage due to repeated attacks.
  • Chronic pain and swelling, joint deformities & formation of tophi (urate crystal deposits)

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents with a sudden onset of severe pain in his left knee, accompanied by swelling and redness. He has a history of elevated uric acid levels. The physician suspects gout and plans to perform a joint aspiration for diagnostic purposes. Which of the following findings would most likely confirm the diagnosis of gout?

options.label: A
options.text: The presence of rhomboid-shaped crystals under polarised light

options.label: B
options.text: Elevated white blood cell count with neutrophilic predominance

options.label: D
options.text: Thickened synovial fluid with a high percentage of lymphocytes

questions.correct_answer: C. Needle-shaped crystals exhibiting negative birefringence
questions.explanation:
Investigations

Description

Joint Aspiration

Investigation of Choice (To confirm a presumptive diagnosis of gout)

Findings: Cloudy synovial fluid; leukocyte count 5,000 to 75,000/μL. Thick, pasty fluid if many crystals.

Crystal Analysis

Type: Needle-shaped monosodium urate (MSU) crystals.

Polarised light: Bright, negative birefringence (yellow parallel, blue perpendicular).

Synovial Fluid Analysis

Staining/Culture: Ruling out septic arthritis, as bacterial infection can coexist with MSU crystals.

Serum Uric Acid Levels

Acute Gout: May be falsely normal or low.

Chronic Gout: Typically elevated.

Additional Laboratory Tests

Serum creatinine: Elevated, indicating renal involvement.

Liver function tests: Assess hepatic function, particularly in older patients.

Serum lipid levels: Elevated in older patients, indicating possible atherosclerosis.

questions.text: A 46-year-old man presents to the OPD with severe pain, redness, and swelling in his right knee. Examination reveals tender swelling and redness at the base of the right 1st toe. Serum urate levels are normal, but arthrocentesis reveals negatively birefringent needle-shaped crystals under polarised light. Which of the following is the drug of choice for this acute attack?
questions.explanation:
Management of acute gout attack

Colchicine

(Option B)
  • Microtubule inhibitor, which prevents microtubule assembly in neutrophils, thus reducing inflammation.
  • Colchicine disrupts the function of the cytoskeleton by inhibiting the polymerization of beta-tubulin into microtubules.
  • This prevents the formation and function of microtubules, which are essential for various cellular processes.
  • By disrupting microtubule formation, colchicine inhibits the activation, degranulation, and migration of neutrophils, which are key players in the inflammatory response. This reduces the inflammatory cascade associated with conditions like gout.
  • Colchicine does not prevent phagocytosis of uric acid crystals, but it inhibits the release of an inflammatory glycoprotein from phagocytes. This contributes to its anti-inflammatory action in conditions like gout.
  • Colchicine blocks metaphase in dividing cells by disrupting mitotic spindle formation.
  • DOC for acute attacks of gout.
  • Dose: 0.6 mg TID - introduced after 2-3 days when swelling reduces.
  • Side effects: Nausea, vomiting and diarrhoea.
  • Avoided in elderly patients and those with renal impairment.

NSAIDs
  • It is effective when used early in an attack of gout.
  • Indomethacin 25-50 mg TID / Naproxen 500 mg BID / Ibuprofen 800 mg TID
  • Avoided in elderly patients and those with renal impairment

Glucocorticoids

(Option C)
  • It can be used as an intramuscular injection for multi-articular involvement or intra-articular injection for mono-articular involvement, or orally.
  • Safe to use in elderly patients and those with renal impairment.

Other treatments

  • Ice therapy: Reduces swelling and inflammation
  • Canakinumab (IL-1 β inhibitor) (Option A)
  • Anakinra: Reserved for resistant cases

Urate lowering agents

  • Drugs: Allopurinol, Febuoxostat, Probenecid and Pegloticase
  • Contraindicated in acute attacks.
  • Rapidly reduces serum urate level, which causes the dissolution of organised monosodium urate crystals.
  • Causes an inflammatory reaction towards the shed crystals.

questions.text: A 48-year-old male presents with a 4-day history of severe pain, swelling, and redness in his right big toe. A diagnosis of acute gout was made, and treatment with NSAIDs resolved his symptoms. Investigations revealed a highly elevated serum uric acid level and increased 24-hour urinary uric acid level. Which anti-gout agent should be used in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Management of gout

Target

Reduce serum urate level to < 5-6 mg / dL

Acute gouty attack

(Anti Inflammatory therapy)
  • Ice pack over swelling
  • NSAIDs (Indomethacin or Naproxen)
  • Oral colchicine 0.6 mg TID - introduced after 2-3 days when swelling reduces
  • Oral prednisolone 15-20 mg daily for 3 days or intramuscular methylprednisolone 80-120 mg daily for 3 days is preferred for elderly patients or polyarticular gout
  • Anakinra - for resistant cases (Option D)

Post-acute attack

(based on 24-hour urinary urate level)

For overproducers

For under producers

  • Allopurinol (Option B): This is a first-line treatment for xanthine oxidase inhibitors. It is typically initiated at 100 mg once daily and can be titrated up to 800 mg as needed.
  • Febuxostat (Option C) is a newer xanthine oxidase inhibitor administered at a dosage of 80-120 mg daily for patients who cannot tolerate allopurinol.
  • Pegloticase (Option A): Recombinant uricase enzyme used in cases resistant to standard therapy.

Uricosuric agents:

  • Probenecid
  • Benzbromarone (withdrawn as it is hepatotoxic)
  • Sulfinpyrazone
 

These agents increase the urinary excretion of uric acid, but they are contraindicated in renal impairment or urolithiasis.

Patients on these drugs need to maintain high fluid intake to prevent urate crystallisation.

Lifestyle measures
  • Weight control
  • Avoid high protein diet
  • Avoid alcohol
  • Avoid stress

Management of gout

Target

Reduce serum urate level to < 5-6 mg / dL

Acute gout attack
  • Ice pack over swelling
  • NSAIDs
  • Oral colchicine
  • Glucocorticoids
  • Anakinra

Post-acute attack

 

For overproduces

For underproduces

  • Allopurinol (1st line)
  • Febuxostat
  • Pegloticase

Uricosuric agents:

  • Probenecid
  • Benzbromarone
  • Sulfinpyrazone

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with stage 2 chronic kidney disease presents with painful swelling at the base of his left big toe. He was diagnosed with an acute gouty attack and treated with oral glucocorticoids. Which anti-gout medication can be used to reduce the risk of another attack without dose modification?
questions.explanation:
Antigout agents safe to use in renal insufficiency

Febuxostat
  • Mechanism of action: Xanthine oxidase inhibitor (more effective than allopurinol)
  • Dose: 80 to 120 mg daily
  • Indications:
    • Patients with the HLA-B* 5801 gene (Southeast Asians, Pacific islanders and blacks)
    • Inadequate response to allopurinol
    • Renal insufficiency (no dose adjustment required as it undergoes hepatic metabolism - glucuronidation and oxidation)
    • Adverse effects of allopurinol
  • It should be initiated during the resolution phase of an acute gout attack, and concurrent anti-inflammatory medications should be provided to prevent flare-ups.

Benzbromarone

  • Uricosuric agent (increases urinary excretion of urate)
  • Safe to use in CKD
  • Withdrawn due to hepatotoxicity

Pegloticase
  • Recombinant uricase enzyme, which is safe to use in CKD
  • Used in cases resistant to standard therapy.

Low dose allopurinol

  • After dose adjustment, allopurinol may be used in patients with renal impairment.
  • The standard dose of 100mg is reduced to 50 mg, which may be gradually increased.

Antigout agents safe to use in renal insufficiency

  • Febuxostat
  • Benzbromarone
  • Pegloticase
  • Low dose allopurinol

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents to the emergency department with sudden swelling, redness, and severe pain in both knees. He has experienced intermittent joint pain for the past few months. Polarised light microscopy of joint aspiration reveals rhomboid-shaped crystals exhibiting positive birefringence. Which statement best explains the pathogenesis of his condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Excessive mechanical wear and tear of the articular cartilage

options.label: B
options.text: Deposition of calcium pyrophosphate crystals in cartilage matrix vesicles

options.label: C
options.text: Excess purine production causes crystal deposition in the joints

options.label: D
options.text: Autoimmune reaction leading to pannus formation in the joint

questions.correct_answer: B. Deposition of calcium pyrophosphate crystals in cartilage matrix vesicles
questions.explanation:
Calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease

Aetiology

  • Ageing
  • Osteoarthritis
  • Post Meniscectomy or joint trauma
  • Familial-genetic
  • Hemochromatosis
  • Hypophosphatasia
  • Hypomagnesemia
  • Certain drugs: Thiazide and loop diuretics
  • Malabsorption
  • Gitelman’s syndrome
  • Gout
  • X-linked hypophosphatemic rickets
  • Familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia

Pathogenesis

  • Mutation in ANKH gene ➜ Increased extracellular transportation of pyrophosphate.
  • Decreased levels of glycosaminoglycans in the cartilage, which results in
    • Increased inorganic pyrophosphate in the cartilage matrix.
    • Calcium combines with this pyrophosphate to form excess CCP.
    • Phagocytosis of CCP crystals by neutrophils and macrophage inflammation.

Clinical features

  • Acute attack may follow surgery (especially parathyroidectomy) and trauma
    • Systemic signs can occur during the attack, such as fever and chills.
    • Joint swelling, redness and pain.
      • Most commonly affected joint: Knees.
      • Rarely affected: First metatarsophalangeal joint.
  • Chronic:
    • Symmetrical Polyarticular arthritis with severe joint damage.
    • Chondrocalcinosis can occur.

Diagnosis

X-ray: Punctate or linear radiodense deposits within fibrocartilaginous joint meniscus or articular hyaline cartilage.

Arthrocentesis: Positively birefringent rhomboid-shaped crystals under polarised light

Features

CPPD (Pseudogout)

Gout

Crystal

Calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate

Monosodium urate

Polarised microscopy

Positively birefringent (rhomboid-shaped crystals)

Negatively birefringent

(needle-shaped crystals)

Common presentation

Acute onset of swelling and pain in large joints (often knees)

Acute onset of severe joint pain, often at the big toe (1st metatarsophalangeal joint)

Joint involvement

Monoarticular or polyarticular

Typically monoarticular

Associated conditions

Osteoarthritis and hypothyroidism

Hyperuricemia and renal disease

Serum uric acid

Normal

Elevated

Chronic effects

May lead to chondrocalcinosis (calcification in cartilage)

Recurrent attacks can lead to tophi. (crystal deposits)

questions.text: A 75-year-old woman presents to the clinic with chronic pain and swelling in her shoulder joint. Radiographs reveal calcific tendinitis in the rotator cuff. A joint aspiration is performed, and the synovial fluid is analysed. If this patient has calcium apatite deposition disease, what type of crystal is most likely to be seen in the patient's synovial fluid?
questions.explanation:
Clinical features

Microscopy of synovial fluid

Gout

(Monosodium urate)
  • Acute onset of severe joint pain, often at the big toe (podagra)
  • Usually monoarticular.

Negatively birefringent needle-shaped crystals (Option C ruled out)

Pseudogout

(Calcium pyrophosphate)
  • Fever and chills
  • Symmetrical polyarticular arthritis
  • Maybe monoarticular
  • Chondrocalcinosis can occur in chronic cases

Positively birefringent rhomboid-shaped crystals (Option A ruled out)

Calcium Apatite deposition disease

  • It usually affects the bursae and tendons around joints.
  • May lead to Milwaukee shoulder in the elderly.
  • Associated with osteoarthritis

Microcrystals of apatite in the synovial fluid show no birefringence under polarised light.

Calcium oxalate deposition disease

  • No specific feature
  • Joint involvement ranges from small to large joints
  • Variable shape and variable birefringence
  • The most easily recognisable crystals are strong birefringent bipyramidal crystals. (Option B ruled out)

questions.text: Match each condition with its corresponding key synovial fluid characteristics: Conditions Key Characteristics 1. Normal a. Yellow, Cloudy, >50,000 WBC 2. Non-inflammatory b. Colorless, Clear, <200 WBC 3. Inflammatory c. Yellow, Opaque, Positive Gram Stain 4. Septic d. Xanthochromic or Red, Bloody 5. Hemarthrosis e. Straw-like, Clear, 200 - 2000 WBC
